content: SECTION 1. TRADE NEGOTIATING OBJECTIVES. Section 1101 of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 is amended to include increased compatibility of trade agreements with environmental protection, conservation, and sustainable development. Principal trade negotiating objectives are also amended to ensure mechanisms within trade agreements for dispute settlement. The Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 is amended to include provisions for more effective dispute resolution, transparency, and enforcement of US rights related to environment and conservation in trade agreements. Developing countries are also addressed in the amendments. The Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 is amended to address the particular needs of developing countries in trade matters related to environment and conservation. Unfair trade practices and intellectual property issues are also revised to include considerations for potentially harmful environmental practices. The Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 is amended to address developing countries' trade needs related to environment and conservation. Amendments include promoting compatibility of WTO standards on intellectual property with international biological diversity conventions and revising foreign investment regulations. The Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 is amended to address developing countries' trade needs related to environment and conservation by promoting environmentally sensitive foreign investment and discouraging countries from relaxing domestic health, safety, or environmental measures to attract or maintain foreign investment. The negotiating objectives of the United States regarding environment and conservation issues related to trade and foreign investment aim to promote compatibility between trade agreements and sustainable development, increase cooperation on trade-related environmental policies, avoid trade distortions that undermine environmental protection, and promote transparency and public participation. The United States aims to promote sustainable forestry practices and increase market access for wood products produced from sustainably harvested timber in trade negotiations. SEC. 2. CITIZEN PARTICIPATION. Section 135 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include nongovernmental environmental and conservation organizations in advisory committees for trade policy and negotiations. Additionally, amendments are made to include environmental and conservation representation in general policy advisory committees. Amendments to Section 135 of the Trade Act of 1974 include adding nongovernmental environmental and conservation organizations to advisory committees for trade policy and negotiations. Environmental and conservation representation is also included in general policy advisory committees. Amendments to Section 135 of the Trade Act of 1974 involve adding environmental and conservation representation to advisory committees for trade policy and negotiations, including nongovernmental organizations. Amendments to Section 135 of the Trade Act of 1974 include adding environmental and conservation representation to advisory committees for trade policy and negotiations, involving various government agencies and executive heads. Amendments to Section 135 of the Trade Act of 1974 involve adding environmental representation to advisory committees for trade policy, including multiple government agencies and executive heads. Amendments to Section 135 of the Trade Act of 1974 involve consulting with advisory committees and private organizations or groups on environmental representation in trade policy. The changes include adding the Interior to the list of Secretaries consulted and inserting "environment and conservation" after "government" in subsection (j). SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL NEGOTIATING OBJECTIVES. Section 1101 of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 is amended to include specific objectives for environment and conservation in the World Trade Organization, focusing on guidelines for national trade measures to protect the environment, transparency in dispute settlement, and improving WTO rules on environmental measures. The World Trade Organization aims to enhance compatibility with international environmental agreements, incentivize environmental issue resolution in trade, improve biodiversity protection through intellectual property rules, establish guidelines for trade in restricted goods, and make progress towards eliminating such goods. The United States aims to eliminate agricultural subsidies that distort trade and harm the environment, create an open process for new trade-related initiatives to promote sustainable development, internalize environmental costs, and enhance environmental protection. Additionally, the US seeks to establish minimum environmental safeguards for countries seeking accession to the North American Free Trade Agreement. The United States aims to establish minimum environmental safeguards for countries seeking accession to trade agreements like the North American Free Trade Agreement and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. This includes implementing additional measures to address country-specific trade and environment issues.
